results.title: He acts his age
results.creator_credit: Judith Crawley and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
How a child’s emotional development normally keeps pace with their physical growth; the behavior they exhibit at certain ages. This introductory film examines the play habits of children from one to fifteen years of age and shows the characteristics of each group.

results.title: From ten to twelve
results.creator_credit: Edmund Reid, Judith Crawley, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
Quite far removed from infancy, yet not across the threshold of adolescence, children of ten to twelve present an absorbing study of adults-in-the-making. We watch the children of one family in various situations in the home, at school and in group play, and find that much of their conflicting behavior is actually a normal part of the growing-up process.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edmund Reid, Judith Crawley, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Spanish and Portugese explorations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Age of Discovery”.
Scenes of Spanish and Portugese towns and photographs of statues, paintings, and other material of historical interest are used to provide a background to the exploration of new routes to the Orient and to the New World. Reference is made to the voyages of Prince Henry the Navigator, Columbus, Vasco Da Gama, Magellan, the Conquistadores, and others.

results.title: English, French and Dutch explorations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Age of Discovery”.
Outlines the reasons behind the explorations of Cabot, Verrazano, Cartier, Frobisher, Hudson, Drake and Raleigh, the routes followed, and how their expeditions affected North America. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Blocking and sampling
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
When setting up an experiment one must consider if the subjects differ in any systematic way that may effect the results. Blocking is used when subjects share the same characteristics but when there may be some variability, as in agricultural experiments, such as the example shown, of testing new varieties of strawberries. A census counts everything but obviously has inherent difficulties which are illustrated. Sampling is a way of circumventing these difficulties and some of the problems of true representation are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

results.title: Always a farmer
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Not just a farmer’s wife, Jenny Grigg, mother of four and business partner in all ways with her husband on their Mallee sheep and grain farm discovered a group of women who were to change Jenny’s life forever.
This story is dedicated to that network of women (PinG) who help and support other farming women in grains by providing inspiration and encouragement and a feeling of self-worth.

results.title: Sustainability
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Althea Hunt describes her life as a farmer’s wife from leaving her beloved family in Queensland to joining her husband and running their independent cereal farm in the Millewa district of Victoria. She talks of the enormous changes - the hard work and dealing with the often unrelenting climate of drought and cyclones whilst also raising three young children and maintaining the family unit. For Althea however, it has been exciting and rewarding to see how far their farm has come over the 30 year journey since she left Queensland.

results.title: Experimental design
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Theresa M. Amabile introduces this first program on the design and conduct of experiments. She discusses the distinction between observational studies and experiments, the concept of control groups to reduce the risk of confounding results and randomized comparative experiments. Examples used are studies of lobsters and how they communicate, the use of aspirin in reducing the incidence of heart attacks and how the police should deal with cases of domestic violence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
